questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for a right ankle injury sustained during a fall earlier that morning. His parents report that he is 'clumsy' when he runs and has fallen multiple times in the last year. He has reached most of his developmental milestones but did not walk until the age of 17 months. He is an only child and was adopted at age 1. He appears tearful and in mild distress. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. His right ankle is mildly swollen with no tenderness over the medial or lateral malleolus; range of motion is full with mild pain. He has marked enlargement of both calves. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Strength is 4/5 in the deltoids, knee flexors/extensors, and 5/5 in the biceps and triceps. Babinski sign is absent. When standing up from a lying position, the patient crawls onto his knees and slowly walks himself up with his hands. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An SMN1 gene defect causes spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), a neurodegenerative autosomal recessive disorder that involves the loss of lower motor neurons. While SMA can present in infancy and childhood with muscle weakness, difficulty walking, the Gower maneuver, reduced reflexes, and pseudohypertrophy of the calves (although less frequently), an SMA patient would likely also present with fasciculations, which are not present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Loss of the ATM protein results in ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T), an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder. Symptoms of A-T commonly begin in childhood before the age of 5 and include difficulty walking and problems with balance and coordination. However, A-T does not result in pseudohypertrophy of the calves and the Gower maneuver. Additionally, individuals with A-T have oculomotor apraxia, myoclonus, frequent infections, and choreoathetoid movements.

C) INCORRECT:

Myotonic protein kinase defects result in myotonic dystrophies type 1 and type 2. Type 1 can manifest in childhood with progressive muscle weakness but involves the facial muscles and intrinsic muscles of the hand and not the proximal muscles seen in this child. Type 2 commonly manifests with mild proximal muscle weakness but onset is usually in adolescence and not in early childhood. Both types can manifest with the Gower maneuver, but they do not present with pseudohypertrophy of the calves.

D) CORRECT:

A truncated or absent dystrophin protein results in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), an X-linked recessive disorder. DMD is diagnosed by testing muscle enzymes like creatine kinase (which are typically elevated), genetic analysis for the dystrophin gene, and muscle biopsy if the genetic analysis is inconclusive. Complications of DMD already arise during adolescence and include dilated cardiomyopathy, cardiac arrhythmias, and respiratory insufficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Arylsulfatase A is an enzyme involved in sphingolipid metabolism, and a deficiency of it causes metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD). While the onset of the late infantile form is between 1–2 years of age and it could be the cause of the muscle weakness and clumsiness seen in this child, MLD also causes muscle rigidity, visual impairment, other developmental delays, and seizures that this child does not display. Additionally, MLD does not cause pseudohypertrophy of the calves.
questions.hint: This 4-year-old boy's combination of delayed walking, reduced muscle reflexes, calf pseudohypertrophy, and use of the Gower maneuver to stand up indicates Duchenne muscular dystrophy, an X-linked disorder.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of nausea and vomiting for 1 day. His maternal uncle had a seizure disorder and died in childhood. He appears fatigued. Respirations are 32/min. Examination shows diffuse weakness in the extremities. Serum studies show a low pH, elevated lactate concentration, and normal blood glucose. A metabolic condition characterized by a defect in oxidative phosphorylation is suspected. Microscopic examination of a muscle biopsy specimen of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers can be seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy and Becker muscular dystrophy. These X-linked disorders most commonly occur in boys 2–5 years of age but are caused by a defect in the dystrophin gene, not in oxidative phosphorylation. Early manifestations typically include paresis and atrophy of the proximal lower limbs. Lactic acidosis is not associated with muscular dystrophies.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of muscle tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is considerable variability in the size of each muscle fiber due to progressive destruction and fibrosis of the myofibres. Many fibroblasts are visible interspersed between the muscle cells and a large necrotic muscle fiber is seen at the left of the image. Much of the normal contractile muscle fibres have been replaced by hypertrophic connective and adipose tissue.

These are characteristic histological features of muscular dystrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Muscle atrophy with perimysial inflammation is seen in dermatomyositis, which results from a CD4+ T cell-mediated immunologic response, not from defective oxidative phosphorylation. Dermatomyositis manifests with muscle weakness, as in this patient, but is typically limited to proximal muscles (most commonly the pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles). Serum studies show elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) and muscle enzymes (creatinine kinase), but lactic acidosis is not associated with the condition. Moreover, this patient does not have characteristic cutaneous manifestations such as heliotrope rash and/or Gottron papules.
Image Description:

Histological section of muscle from the upper thigh (H&E stain)

In addition to the normal musculature, the following pathological findings are visible: pronounced interstitial (green overlay) and perivascular lymphocytic infiltration (V = vessel), muscle fiber necrosis and resorption (green arrow), and perifascicular atrophy (green hatched area), which is characteristic of dermatomyositis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is characteristic of McArdle disease, a disorder in which the muscle is unable to break down glycogen. It commonly manifests in adolescence or early adulthood with muscle cramps, weakness, and myoglobinuria following exercise. Due to the lack of myophosphorylase, affected patients show a flat increase in lactate level during exercise testing, unlike the elevated lactate levels in this patient. Oxidative phosphorylation is unaffected by McArdle disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Endomysial inflammation with CD8+ T-cell infiltration is a typical finding in polymyositis (PM), which is presumably caused by an autoimmune reaction against skeletal muscle antigens, not by defective oxidative phosphorylation. PM presents with muscle weakness, as in this patient, but is typically limited to proximal muscles (most commonly the pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles). Serum studies show elevated inflammatory markers and muscle enzymes, but lactate acidosis is not associated with PM.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's lactic acidosis and diffuse muscle weakness in combination with the family history of CNS disease and childhood death suggest a form of mitochondrial myopathy, most likely MELAS syndrome. Subsarcolemmal and intermyofibrillar accumulation of mitochondria in muscle fibers is a hallmark of mitochondrial diseases, which are characterized by defective oxidative phosphorylation and subsequent lack of energy. The compensatory proliferation of mitochondria presents as characteristic ragged-red fibers on Gomori trichrome stain.
questions.hint: This patient's diffuse muscle weakness and lactic acidosis are most likely due to a maternally inherited condition.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive difficulty climbing stairs for the last 2 years. During this period, he has also had problems running and standing up from a seated position. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows enlarged calf muscles bilaterally and a waddling gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonsense mutations are point mutations that cause insertion of a premature stop codon, which results in a nonfunctional protein or gene product. About 10%–15% of cases of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) are due to a nonsense mutation in the dystrophin gene. The disease typically manifests in boys with symptoms identical to BMD such as progressive muscle weakness and calf pseudohypertrophy, which are seen in this patient. However, symptoms manifest during infancy or early childhood and are more severe than in BMD.

As certain nonsense mutations can induce exon skipping and thereby produce various phenotypes, nonsense mutations within exon 1 or 27 have indeed been associated with a BMD phenotype. However, these mutations are exceptions, and another mechanism is much more likely in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder that is most commonly caused by an in-frame deletion in the dystrophin gene, which leads to a partially functional protein. In in-frame mutations, multiples of three nucleotides (i.e., complete codons) are added or deleted, leaving the reading frame intact. The second most common cause of BMD is a missense mutation, where a single nucleotide is substituted. BMD usually manifests in boys during adolescence or early adulthood with slow, progressive muscle weakness and calf pseudohypertrophy, as seen in this patient. Symptoms are typically less severe and appear later than in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Genetic analysis for mutations in the dystrophin gene is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of dystrophinopathies.

C) INCORRECT:

Trinucleotide repeat expansions cause a variety of diseases including myotonic dystrophy (MD, CTG repeats) and Friedreich ataxia (FA, GAA repeats). MD and FA both manifest with progressive weakness. However, MD is associated with muscle pain and atrophy (not pseudohypertrophy), and patients often develop cardiac arrhythmias, testicular atrophy, frontal baldness, and/or cataracts, which are not seen this patient. While FA also manifests with gait difficulties, this is due to a spastic paresis that affects the entire lower leg, leading to a wide-based, staggering gait, which is not present in this patient. Moreover, one would expect an onset of symptoms during childhood and different findings, including nystagmus, diabetes mellitus, and skeletal deformities. FA does not cause calf pseudohypertrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Splice site mutations are associated with a variety of diseases including cancers, dementia, epilepsy, and some types of β-thalassemia. However, they are not an underlying cause of muscular dystrophy.

E) INCORRECT:

Frameshift mutations cause insertion or deletion of nucleotides, which changes the originally-encoded sequence of triplets and thus shifts the way it is read during translation. X-linked recessive frameshift mutations of the dystrophin gene are a common cause of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). The disease typically manifests in boys with symptoms identical to BMD such as progressive muscle weakness and calf pseudohypertrophy, which are seen in this patient. However, symptoms in DMD manifest during infancy or early childhood and are more severe than symptoms in BMD.
questions.hint: Proximal muscle weakness in the lower extremities (difficulty climbing stairs, standing from a seated position, waddling gait), bilateral calf pseudohypertrophy, and onset of symptoms during adolescence is highly suggestive of Becker muscular dystrophy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of clumsiness and multiple falls over the past 4 months. He started walking at the age of 18 months and could walk up steps by the time he was 27 months old but now struggles to walk at all without assistance. When standing up from a lying position, he crawls onto his knees and slowly walks himself up with his hands. There is bilateral calf enlargement. Analysis of a left calf biopsy specimen from this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Perivascular inflammation with muscle fiber ischemia and atrophy
Proliferation of mitochondria within muscle fibers
Degeneration of muscle fibers with fibrofatty replacement
Atrophic muscle fibers interspersed among hypertrophic muscle fibers
Necrotic muscle fibers with lymphocytic infiltrate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Perivascular inflammation with muscle fiber ischemia and atrophy would be consistent with dermatomyositis., which is typically characterized by proximal and symmetrical muscle weakness, especially of the pelvic and shoulder girdle. However, in a patient with dermatomyositis, skin involvement would be expected (e.g., Gottron papules or heliotrope rash), while calf pseudohypertrophy would not.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitochondrial myopathies are characterized by the appearance of red ragged fibers due to the proliferation of mitochondria within muscle fibers. As the respiratory chain of enzymes is impaired, the proliferation of mitochondria acts as a compensatory mechanism. There are different forms of mitochondrial myopathies, but patients usually present with muscle weakness that is exacerbated by exertion. Neither the Gower sign nor calf pseudohypertrophy are features of mitochondrial myopathies.

C) CORRECT:

Degeneration of muscle fibers with fibrofatty replacement is the underlying pathology of muscular dystrophies such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Muscle fiber degeneration occurs due to dystrophin gene mutations, which lead to alterations of the dystrophin protein. Complete impairment of dystrophin results in disturbance of cellular signaling pathways, which promotes necrosis in these cells. Subsequently, these muscle cells are replaced with connective and fat tissue and the muscle appears larger (calf pseudohypertrophy).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of muscle tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is considerable variability in the size of each muscle fiber due to progressive destruction and fibrosis of the myofibres. Many fibroblasts are visible interspersed between the muscle cells and a large necrotic muscle fiber is seen at the left of the image. Much of the normal contractile muscle fibres have been replaced by hypertrophic connective and adipose tissue.

These are characteristic histological features of muscular dystrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Atrophic muscle fibers interspersed among hypertrophic muscle fibers would be found in spinal muscular atrophy. While spinal muscular atrophy can manifest with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty walking, Gower sign, and calf pseudohypertrophy, a patient with this disease would most likely also present with fasciculations and varying degrees of bulbar palsy, neither of which are present.

E) INCORRECT:

Necrotic muscle fibers with a lymphocytic infiltrate would be consistent with polymyositis, which is characterized by proximal and symmetrical muscle weakness, especially of the pelvic and shoulder girdle. However, the age of onset in polymyositis is usually older than 20 years and calf pseudohypertrophy would not be expected.
questions.hint: The presence of calf pseudohypertrophy and the Gower sign in this patient are highly suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after falling. He has fallen multiple times in the last year. His parents report that he did not walk until he was 18 months old. Examination shows a mildly swollen right ankle with no tenderness over the medial or lateral malleolus; range of motion is full with mild pain. He has marked enlargement of both calves. When standing up, the patient uses his hands against his knees and thighs to slowly push himself up into a standing position. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's fall?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Loss of the ATM protein results in ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T), an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder. Symptoms of A-T commonly begin in childhood before the age of 5 and include difficulty walking and problems with balance and coordination, as seen in this patient. However, A-T does not result in pseudohypertrophy of the calves and the Gower maneuver. Additionally, individuals with A-T have oculomotor apraxia, myoclonus, frequent infections, and choreoathetoid movements, which are not seen in this child.

B) CORRECT:

The absence of dystrophin protein results in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), an X-linked recessive disorder. DMD is diagnosed by testing muscle enzymes like creatine kinase (which are typically elevated), genetic analysis for the dystrophin gene, and muscle biopsy if genetic analysis is inconclusive. Complications of DMD already arise during adolescence and include dilated cardiomyopathy, cardiac arrhythmias, and respiratory insufficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Myotonic protein kinase defects result in myotonic dystrophies type 1 and type 2. Type 1 can present in childhood with progressive muscle weakness but involves the facial muscles and intrinsic muscles of the hand and not the proximal muscles seen in this child. Type 2 commonly presents with mild proximal muscle weakness but onset is usually in adolescence and not in early childhood, as seen here. Both types can present with the Gower maneuver, as seen above, but they do not cause pseudohypertrophy of the calves.

D) INCORRECT:

Arylsulfatase A is an enzyme involved in sphingolipid metabolism, and a deficiency of it causes metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD). While the onset of the late infantile form is between 1–2 years of age and it could be the cause of the muscle weakness and clumsiness seen in this child, MLD also causes muscle rigidity, visual impairment, other developmental delays and seizures that this child does not display. Additionally, MLD does not cause pseudohypertrophy of the calves.

E) INCORRECT:

An SMN1 gene defect causes spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), a neurodegenerative autosomal recessive disorder that involves the loss of lower motor neurons. While SMA can present during infancy and childhood with muscle weakness, difficulty walking, reduced reflexes, and rarely the Gower maneuver and pseudohypertrophy of the calves, a patient with SMA would likely also present with fasciculations, which are not present in this patient.
questions.hint: This boy's developmental delay in walking, enlargement of the calves (calf pseudohypertrophy), and use of the Gower maneuver (walking hands up thigh into a standing position) is consistent with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (X-linked recessive disorder)

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of chest discomfort and progressive dyspnea. He cannot do daily chores without feeling out of breath. He has a history of an X-linked recessive disorder that causes progressive proximal muscle weakness and gait abnormalities. Physical examination shows a waddling gait and weak patellar reflexes. Cardiovascular examination shows a holosystolic murmur, displaced point of maximal impulse, and bilateral pitting edema of the ankle. Laboratory studies show elevated levels of brain natriuretic peptide. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's muscle weakness?

choices.text: Impaired connection of cytoskeletal actin filaments to membrane-bound dystroglycan
Reduced nicotinic acetylcholine receptor density on sarcolemma
Interruption of microtubule depolymerization through stabilization of GDP-tubulin
Cell–mediated cytotoxicity against skeletal muscle antigens in the endomysium
Increased number of CTG repeats in the DMPK gene

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In Becker muscular dystrophy, mutations of the dystrophin gene lead to alterations in dystrophin protein structure, impairing the connection of cytoskeletal actin filaments to membrane-bound dystroglycan. Dystrophin is present in the cytoplasm of skeletal and cardiac muscle cells. When functionally normal, it provides muscle fibers with strength and stiffness. Becker muscular dystrophy is characterized by pelvic girdle weakness and gait abnormalities and can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy, which typically manifests with heart failure and arrhythmias late in the disease course.

B) INCORRECT:

In Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), defective lysine-hydroxylysine crosslinking of tropocollagen leads to unstable collagen fibrils. The condition usually causes hyperextensible skin and joint hypermobility. Cardiac manifestations are also common, especially mitral valve prolapse (MVP) or dilation of the aortic root with possible subsequent aortic regurgitation and, ultimately, heart failure. Unlike this patient's findings, a midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur would be expected for MVP, while a decrescendo diastolic murmur would be expected for aortic regurgitation. Furthermore, progressive proximal muscle weakness and gait abnormalities, as seen in this patient, are not typical features of EDS.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduced nicotinic acetylcholine receptor density on the sarcolemma occurs in myasthenia gravis. In this autoimmune disease, these receptors are also blocked by autoantibodies. Myasthenia gravis classically manifests with ptosis and diplopia, which worsen with prolonged muscle use and improve with the administration of edrophonium. However, general proximal muscle weakness and heart failure are not common features of myasthenia gravis. In addition, myasthenia gravis is not inherited in an X-linked fashion.
Image Description:

Blockade of ACh receptors (Left): ACh antibodies bind to postsynaptic ACh receptors and inhibit muscle activation.

Receptor internalization/degradation (middle): Binding of ACh antibody results in accelerated receptor degradation. The receptor is internalized and degraded by the muscle cell.

Complement activation (right): Binding of ACh autoantibodies results in complement activation and membrane attack complex formation, leading to the destruction of the neuromuscular junction and muscle cell lysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Interruption of microtubule depolymerization through the stabilization of GDP-tubulin is the mechanism of action of a group of chemotherapeutic agents called taxanes. Taxanes, e.g., paclitaxel, have significant side effects, including myelosuppression and peripheral neuropathy. However, progressive muscle weakness and heart failure would not be expected. Furthermore, because this patient has no history of cancer, there is no indication for treatment with a taxane.

E) INCORRECT:

Cell-mediated cytotoxicity against skeletal muscle antigens in the endomysium causes chronic inflammation of skeletal muscle, as seen in inflammatory myopathies such as polymyositis. Patients with polymyositis classically present with proximal muscle weakness (i.e., of the shoulder and pelvic girdle muscles). Advanced polymyositis may manifest with dysphagia and aspiration caused by oropharyngeal muscle involvement. However, cardiac muscle involvement and global heart failure, as seen in this patient, are not associated with polymyositis. Furthermore, these conditions are not inherited in an X-linked fashion.

F) INCORRECT:

CTG repeats in the region of the DMPK gene cause a deficiency of myotonin-protein kinase in skeletal and heart muscle tissue. CTG repeats in the DMPK gene are the underlying pathology of myotonic dystrophy type 1 (MDT1), which manifests with myotonia, muscular atrophy, balding, cataracts, and arrhythmias. However, this patient has none of these cardiovascular findings. Moreover, MDT1 is an autosomal dominant condition.
questions.hint: Signs of global heart failure caused by dilated cardiomyopathy include progressive dyspnea, a holosystolic murmur, displaced point of maximal impulse, pitting edema, and elevated levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP). In combination with a history of genetic disease involving muscle weakness, these signs are consistent with Becker muscular dystrophy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of worsening mobility issues. During this period, his parents noticed that he had occasional falls and increasing difficulties climbing stairs and running. The boy had a normal development up until then; he was able to walk by the age of 15 months. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He takes no medications and immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Musculoskeletal examination shows enlarged calf muscles bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ on the lower extremities and 2+ on the upper extremities. He has a waddling gait and when asked to get up from the floor, he supports himself with his hands on his legs to get to an upright position. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

DMD is an x-linked recessive disease characterized by progressive muscle paresis and atrophy that typically starts in the pelvic girdle, as seen in this patient. Because DMD results in a deficiency of dystrophin, affected muscle cells die, leading to elevated serum levels of creatine kinase (CK). In almost all cases of DMD, serum CK levels are 20–100 times the upper limit of the reference range by the age of 2 years (i.e., even before the onset of symptoms of DMD) and then decline at the rate of approx. 25% per year due to progressive replacement of muscle tissue by fat and fibrotic tissue. If DMD is suspected, serum CK concentration should be obtained as the first step in diagnosis and genetic analysis for DMD gene mutations should then be performed to confirm the diagnosis. If the CK level is normal or only mildly increased at the time of symptom onset, DMD is unlikely and a different condition (e.g., spinal muscular atrophy) should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Electromyography (EMG) in DMD might show pathological changes consistent with myopathy, such as polyphasic motor unit potentials and increased motor unit recruitment. However, EMG has a relatively high false-negative rate for DMD, especially in the early stages of the disease, and this test requires the patient's active cooperation, which is difficult to achieve in very young children, like this patient. Electrodiagnostic studies such as EMG and nerve conduction studies are only considered in atypical cases to rule out neurogenic disorders such as spinal muscular atrophy.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac arrhythmias and dilated cardiomyopathy caused by cardiac muscle fibrosis are common life-threatening complications of DMD. Therefore, patients with DMD require ECG and echocardiography at the time of diagnosis (to establish baseline findings) and then at least annually for surveillance. However, cardiac complications of DMD typically arise during adolescence; toddlers with DMD usually do not have evidence of cardiac disease. A different initial diagnostic step is more appropriate for the diagnosis of DMD.

D) INCORRECT:

As DMD is characterized by a deficiency of dystrophin, muscle biopsy showing the absence of dystrophin can confirm the diagnosis. However, a muscle biopsy is an invasive procedure and is only performed if other, less invasive tests are unavailable or inconclusive.

E) INCORRECT:

Genetic analysis is a complex and expensive procedure and is only performed if the results of another initial step are suggestive of DMD. Genetic analysis is used to confirm the diagnosis of DMD.
questions.hint: This boy presents with a waddling gait, hyporeflexia in the lower extremities, bilateral calf pseudohypertrophy, and Gower sign. The early onset of these symptoms suggests Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 9-month history of progressive difficulty walking and muscle weakness that has forced him to quit his cycling team. During this period, he also has had problems climbing stairs and standing up from a seated position. He is at the 65th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows enlargement of both calf muscles and a waddling gait. Serum creatine kinase concentration is 540 U/L. Genetic analysis shows an in-frame deletion in the dystrophin gene. This patient is at greatest risk of dying from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Congestive heart failure from dilated cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of death in patients with Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD). The in-frame deletion affecting the dystrophin gene causes a partially functional dystrophin protein, which leads to muscle tissue necrosis and subsequent cardiac fibrosis. Although patients with BMD generally have less severe musculoskeletal symptoms with a slower disease progression than patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), cardiac involvement is more common and is a considerable cause of morbidity.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with progressive muscular dystrophies (e.g., BMD, Duchenne muscular dystrophy) have an increased risk of mild cognitive impairment and certain psychiatric conditions (e.g., obsessive-compulsive disorder, autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder). Dementia most commonly manifests in old age; individuals with BMD have a life expectancy of 40–50 years, so dementia is not a common cause of death in this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with BMD have a slightly increased risk of urinary tract infection, which can lead to urosepsis, due to the increased prevalence of urological abnormalities (e.g., urinary incontinence, detrusor overactivity, voiding dysfunction). However, urosepsis is not the most common cause of death in individuals with BMD.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with BMD are at increased risk of immobilization due to potential loss of ambulation, which is a risk factor for venous thromboembolism (e.g., deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism). However, pulmonary embolism is not the most common cause of death in patients with BMD.

E) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is one of the leading causes of death in the United States. However, CAD is not the most common cause of death in patients with BMD. Muscular dystrophies affect the dystrophin protein, which is found in muscle cells rather than in vascular cells.
questions.hint: This adolescent patient's features (difficulty standing from a seated position, waddling gait, bilateral calf pseudohypertrophy) in conjunction with markedly elevated creatine kinase (CK) and an in-frame deletion of the dystrophin gene, are suggestive of Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD).

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man with Duchenne muscular dystrophy reports increasing disability, including leg weakness and difficulty walking. On examination, he has scoliosis and diffuse proximal muscle weakness.
In addition to multidisciplinary supportive care, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A balanced diet with healthy protein content, rather than one high in carbohydrates, should be overseen by a nutritionist. Carnitine supplements have not been shown to be effective.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose glucocorticoids are not recommended in this setting because the adverse effects of these medications would outweigh any benefits.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive physical activity, such as an intensive aerobic exercise program or high-resistance strength training, can worsen muscular dystrophy and should be avoided.

D) INCORRECT:

Quinine may be useful to promote muscle relaxation but is not effective for a patient with progressive muscular weakness.

E) CORRECT:

Management of muscular dystrophy focuses on symptomatic therapy and supportive care. The American Academy of Neurology recommends offering low-dose prednisone (0.75 mg/kg/day) or deflazacort (0.9 mg/kg/day) to patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy to improve strength and pulmonary function. New therapies that target the genetic mutation of Duchenne muscular dystrophy are available in some countries, but the clinical benefit is still not clear and they are not appropriate for every patient.

Key learning point: The two medication options recommended for improving strength and pulmonary function in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy are low-dose prednisone and deflazacort.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy who is adopted and whose biological family history is unknown presents for evaluation of unsteadiness. His parents report that he is clumsy and falls frequently when walking; they also note that he runs on his tiptoes and has difficulty getting up from a sitting position. He has mild language delay but is otherwise developing normally.
His vital signs and physical examination are normal except that his calves are visibly enlarged but nontender, and he has reduced bilateral strength in his deltoids and knee extensors and flexors (+4/5). When on the floor, he rises to standing by crouching on all fours and walking his hands up his shins.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spinal muscular atrophy type 1 manifests at a much earlier age with severe hypotonia, marked weakness, and associated muscle fasciculations.

B) INCORRECT:

Myotonic dystrophy manifests at a later age with facial weakness, myotonia, greater distal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrine problems, and cardiac conduction disturbances and muscle involvement leading to arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy.

C) CORRECT:

The most likely diagnosis in a 5-year-old boy with proximal muscle weakness, abnormal gait, and enlarged calves is Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is the most common of the muscular dystrophies. It is an X-linked disorder, and the genetic mutation prevents the production of functional dystrophin.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy manifests insidiously; the first sign is usually a delay in walking. Almost all children with the disease show signs by 5 years of age, including a waddling gait, inability to run, toe walking, frequent falling, and pseudohypertrophy of the calves. The classic Gowers sign — in which a patient uses his hands and arms to "walk" up his body from a squatting position — indicates lower limb proximal weakness.

The disease is progressive, and affected boys usually require a wheelchair by 13 years of age. In 30% of cases, there is associated central nervous system involvement with lower intelligence.

Creatine kinase levels are highly elevated in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (50 to 100 times higher than normal levels during the first stages of the disease), and the diagnosis is made by polymerase chain-reaction identification of the gene mutation. In a minority of cases, the genetic test is inconclusive, and a muscle biopsy is needed.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a 5-year-old boy with proximal muscle weakness, abnormal gait, and enlarged calves is Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Becker muscular dystrophy affects dystrophin, but the dystrophin remains partially active. This disease tends to be milder than Duchenne muscular dystrophy and to manifest later in life. Both conditions are associated with cardiomyopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Juvenile dermatomyositis manifests with both proximal muscle weakness and skin manifestations, including a heliotrope rash and Gottron papules (multiple violaceous, scaly papules overlying joints, often of the dorsal hand).

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy reports increasing disability, including leg weakness and difficulty walking. On examination, he has scoliosis and diffuse proximal muscle weakness.
In addition to multidisciplinary supportive care, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Management of muscular dystrophy focuses on symptomatic therapy and supportive care. The American Academy of Neurology recommends offering low-dose prednisone (0.75 mg/kg/day) to patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy to improve strength and pulmonary function. This is associated with adverse effects, including weight gain, hirsutism, and cushingoid appearance.

Key learning point: The intervention that is recommended for improving strength and pulmonary function in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy is low-dose prednisone.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose glucocorticoids are not recommended in this setting because the adverse effects of these medications would outweigh any benefits.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive physical activity, as in an aerobic exercise program, can worsen muscular dystrophy and should be avoided.

D) INCORRECT:

A balanced diet with healthy protein content, rather than one high in carbohydrates, should be overseen by a nutritionist. Carnitine supplements have not been shown to be effective.

E) INCORRECT:

Quinine may be useful to promote muscle relaxation but is not effective for a patient with progressive muscular weakness.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought in by his mother for evaluation of weakness that she first noticed about 6 months ago. It started in his thighs, but his arms have become progressively weaker as well. Recently, she has noticed that he has been falling and is no longer able to run as well as his peers. He has not experienced any trauma, been ill, or received any vaccines recently. He has met all his developmental milestones on time and began walking at about 13 months of age.
On physical examination, his vital signs are within normal limits for his age. He is at the 70th percentile for weight and the 60th percentile for height. His cardiac, respiratory, and abdominal examinations are normal. Cranial nerves II-XII are intact. His calf muscles appear to be enlarged. When asked to rise from a chair, he appears weak and must walk his hands up his legs to stand upright. He then walks on his tiptoes.
Laboratory testing reveals a creatine kinase level of 17,000 U/liter (reference range, 20–200). An electrocardiogram and echocardiogram are ordered.
Cardiac evaluation is required in this patient to assess for which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic insufficiency and mitral valve prolapse are not associated with DMD.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic insufficiency and mitral valve prolapse are not associated with DMD.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter) may occur in DMD, and as ventricular dysfunction progresses, ventricular arrhythmias may also develop. LV dysfunction predominantly precedes rhythm abnormalities. Thus, at the time of DMD diagnosis, the primary goal of cardiac screening is to identify LV dysfunction.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), a progressive neuromuscular disorder that is inherited through an X-linked recessive pattern. The disorder is related to a mutation in the gene that encodes the protein dystrophin, which makes up the complex connecting the cytoskeleton of the muscle fiber to the extracellular matrix. Progressive muscle damage leads to weakness, motor delays, respiratory insufficiency, and cardiac involvement.

DMD typically manifests in the early years of life with progressive muscle weakness that begins in the proximal leg muscles and pelvis, and then in the upper arms and shoulders. Affected children have an abnormal gait and typically walk on tiptoes, which is a compensatory mechanism for knee-extensor weakness; they also have difficulty running or jumping and frequently fall. Examination findings typically include pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles, as the muscle is replaced by fat, and a positive Gowers sign, in which the seated patient must walk his hands up his legs in order to stand. Affected patients may also develop muscle contractures, muscle wasting, scoliosis, and difficulty swallowing; by the second decade of life, they are no longer able to walk. Restrictive lung disease is also common, as the muscles required for breathing become more severely involved, and can lead to respiratory failure.

Diagnosis of DMD includes measuring the creatine kinase (CK) level, which is at least 10 times the normal value. If the CK level is elevated, the patient should undergo genetic testing targeting the dystrophin gene. If the results of the genetic test are negative, but there is still clinical suspicion for DMD, a muscle biopsy can be obtained, to evaluate for the presence of dystrophin.

Cardiac involvement is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with DMD. The most common type is left ventricular (LV) dysfunction, which then progresses to dilation of the left ventricle. Patients should undergo a screening electrocardiogram and echocardiogram at the time of DMD diagnosis — and, if asymptomatic, every 2 years until age 10 and then annually after 10 years. Asymptomatic patients with findings of LV dysfunction or arrhythmia should be screened more frequently, as should patients who are symptomatic with signs of heart failure, including shortness of breath, tachypnea, orthopnea, or fatigue.

Thus, at the time of DMD diagnosis, the primary goal of cardiac screening is to identify LV dysfunction.

Key learning point: In patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, echocardiograms are required at diagnosis and serially over time to evaluate for left ventricular dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Myofibrillar myopathies are associated with cardiomyopathies, including hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, whereas DMD is associated with a dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of progressive difficulty climbing stairs over the past 2 years. During this period, he has also had occasional falls and problems with running and standing from a chair. He has not had any vision problems or muscle cramping. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally, and sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Musculoskeletal examination shows enlarged calf muscles bilaterally. He has a waddling gait. Serum studies show a creatine kinase concentration of 1700 U/L. Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An edrophonium test is used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis (MG), which can cause proximal muscle weakness. The clinical course of MG, however, is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with use (e.g., worse at the end of the day or with exercise). Also, the majority of patients with MG have ocular muscle involvement, with complaints of double vision and/or drooping eyelids. Serum creatine kinase concentrations are typically normal in patients with MG.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies may be seen in patients with inflammatory myopathies (e.g., polymyositis), which can result in proximal muscle weakness and an increased serum creatine kinase concentration. The presence of calf hypertrophy, however, suggests that the diagnosis is a dystrophinopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

A relative deficiency of dystrophin on histochemical staining of a muscle specimen is a specific finding that would confirm the diagnosis of Becker muscular dystrophy. However, a muscle biopsy is an invasive procedure; a test that is less invasive, more specific, and more sensitive is currently preferred as a first-line test to confirm the diagnosis of dystrophinopathy. Muscle biopsies are performed when the first-line test is either unavailable or inconclusive.

D) INCORRECT:

Electromyography in a patient with a dystrophinopathy, such as Becker muscular dystrophy, would show spontaneous fibrillation potentials and polyphasic, motor unit action potentials with a decreased amplitude, short duration, and increased recruitment of motor units. These findings, however, can be seen in most myopathies and are not specific to dystrophinopathies; a different test is indicated to confirm the diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Genetic analysis for mutations in the dystrophin gene is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of dystrophinopathies, such as Becker muscular dystrophy or Duchenne muscular dystrophy. This patient most likely has Becker dystrophy, an X-linked recessive genetic disease in which mutations in the dystrophin gene lead to dysfunctional protein products, with subsequent degeneration of muscle fibers and progressive proximal muscle weakness. Affected patients may be ambulatory for part of their adult lives, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has gait abnormalities, bilateral calf pseudohypertrophy, and increased creatine kinase in serum. These symptoms are suggestive of muscular dystrophy, most likely Becker muscular dystrophy considering the late onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy reports increasing disability, including leg weakness and difficulty walking. On examination, he has scoliosis and diffuse proximal muscle weakness. C) INCORRECT:

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has progressive difficulty climbing stairs and rising from the floor. On exam, he uses his hands to push on his legs when standing. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Degeneration of anterior horn cells due to SMN1 mutation
Mitochondrial conduction defect causing lactic acidosis
Autosomal recessive deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the SMN1 gene cause spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), a neurogenic disorder with anterior horn cell degeneration. SMA presents with hypotonia, muscle atrophy, and diminished reflexes, often earlier than age 5. The boy's use of Gower's maneuver indicates proximal muscle weakness typical of a myopathy, not SMA.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitochondrial disorders can cause exercise intolerance and lactic acidosis, often with multisystem involvement. The boy's progressive proximal muscle weakness and use of Gower's maneuver suggest a structural muscle protein disorder, not a mitochondrial defect. The absence of systemic symptoms or elevated lactate levels further reduces the likelihood of a mitochondrial disorder.

C) CORRECT:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome, following an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern. These mutations often result in a frameshift, leading to a complete absence of dystrophin, a protein essential for muscle fiber integrity. The lack of dystrophin causes muscle fibers to be susceptible to damage, leading to progressive muscle weakness and replacement by fat and fibrous tissue. Clinically, affected boys present with difficulty climbing stairs and using their hands to push on their legs when standing, known as Gower's sign.

Key learning point: A positive Gower's sign is a classic finding in Duchenne muscular dystrophy, indicating proximal muscle weakness.

D) INCORRECT:

Alpha-galactosidase A deficiency characterizes Fabry disease, a lysosomal storage disorder with X-linked inheritance. It manifests with angiokeratomas, acroparesthesia, and renal and cardiovascular complications. The absence of these symptoms and the presence of proximal muscle weakness in the boy suggest a muscular dystrophy rather than a lysosomal storage disorder.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man presents to the office with a 6-month history of chest discomfort and progressive dyspnea. He cannot do daily chores without feeling out of breath. He has a history of an X-linked recessive disorder that causes progressive proximal muscle weakness and gait abnormalities. Physical examination reveals:

Waddling gait
Exaggerated lumbar lordosis
Positive Trendelenburg test bilaterally
Weak patellar reflexes bilaterally

Cardiovascular examination reveals a holosystolic murmur, a displaced point of maximal impulse, and bilateral pitting edema of the ankles. Laboratory studies reveal elevated levels of brain natriuretic peptide. The most likely underlying cause of this patient's muscle weakness is

choices.text: reduced nicotinic acetylcholine receptor density on sarcolemma
an increased number of CTG repeats in the DMPK gene
impaired connection of cytoskeletal actin filaments to membrane-bound dystroglycan
cell–mediated cytotoxicity against skeletal muscle antigens in the endomysium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reduced nicotinic acetylcholine receptor density on the sarcolemma occurs in myasthenia gravis. In this autoimmune disease, these receptors are also blocked by autoantibodies. Myasthenia gravis classically manifests with ptosis and diplopia, which worsen with prolonged muscle use and improve with the administration of edrophonium. However, general proximal muscle weakness and heart failure are not common features of myasthenia gravis. In addition, myasthenia gravis is not inherited in an X-linked fashion.

B) INCORRECT:

CTG repeats in the region of the DMPK gene cause a deficiency of myotonin-protein kinase in skeletal and heart muscle tissue. CTG repeats in the DMPK gene are the underlying pathology of myotonic dystrophy type 1 (MDT1), which manifests with myotonia, muscular atrophy, balding, cataracts, and arrhythmias. However, this patient has none of these cardiovascular findings. Moreover, MDT1 is an autosomal dominant condition.

C) CORRECT:

In Becker muscular dystrophy, mutations of the dystrophin gene lead to alterations in dystrophin protein structure, impairing the connection of cytoskeletal actin filaments to membrane-bound dystroglycan. Dystrophin is present in the cytoplasm of skeletal and cardiac muscle cells. When functionally normal, it provides muscle fibers with strength and stiffness. Becker muscular dystrophy is characterized by pelvic girdle weakness and gait abnormalities and can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy, which typically manifests with heart failure and arrhythmias late in the disease course.

D) INCORRECT:

Cell-mediated cytotoxicity against skeletal muscle antigens in the endomysium causes chronic inflammation of skeletal muscle, as seen in inflammatory myopathies such as polymyositis. Patients with polymyositis classically present with proximal muscle weakness (i.e., of the shoulder and pelvic girdle muscles). Advanced polymyositis may manifest with dysphagia and aspiration caused by oropharyngeal muscle involvement. However, cardiac muscle involvement and global heart failure, as seen in this patient, are not associated with polymyositis. Furthermore, these conditions are not inherited in an X-linked fashion.

E) INCORRECT:

In Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), defective lysine-hydroxylysine crosslinking of tropocollagen leads to unstable collagen fibrils. The condition usually causes hyperextensible skin and joint hypermobility. Cardiac manifestations are also common, especially mitral valve prolapse (MVP) or dilation of the aortic root with possible subsequent aortic regurgitation and, ultimately, heart failure. Unlike this patient's findings, a midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur would be expected for MVP, while a decrescendo diastolic murmur would be expected for aortic regurgitation. Furthermore, progressive proximal muscle weakness and gait abnormalities, as seen in this patient, are not typical features of EDS.
questions.hint: Signs of global heart failure caused by dilated cardiomyopathy include progressive dyspnea, a holosystolic murmur, displaced point of maximal impulse, pitting edema, and elevated levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP). In combination with a history of genetic disease involving muscle weakness, these signs are consistent with Becker muscular dystrophy.

questions.text: You are seeing a 16-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic by his parents because of a 9-month history of progressive difficulty walking and muscle weakness, which has led him to quit his cycling team. He has also had increasing difficulty climbing stairs and standing up from a seated position during this time. His height and weight are at the 65th percentile. On examination, he has enlargement of both calf muscles and a waddling gait. Serum creatine kinase concentration is 540 IU/L (30–250). Genetic analysis reveals an in-frame deletion in the dystrophin gene. This patient is at greatest risk of dying from which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with progressive muscular dystrophies (e.g., BMD, Duchenne muscular dystrophy) have an increased risk of mild cognitive impairment and certain psychiatric conditions (e.g., obsessive-compulsive disorder, autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder). Dementia most commonly manifests in old age; individuals with BMD have a life expectancy of 40–50 years, so dementia is not a common cause of death in this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is one of the leading causes of death in the United States. However, CAD is not the most common cause of death in patients with BMD. Muscular dystrophies affect the dystrophin protein, which is found in muscle cells rather than in vascular cells.

C) CORRECT:

Congestive heart failure from dilated cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of death in patients with Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD). The in-frame deletion affecting the dystrophin gene causes a partially functional dystrophin protein, which leads to muscle tissue necrosis and subsequent cardiac fibrosis. Although patients with BMD generally have less severe musculoskeletal symptoms with a slower disease progression than patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), cardiac involvement is more common and is a considerable cause of morbidity.

Key learning point: Congestive heart failure from dilated cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of death in Becker muscular dystrophy due to cardiac involvement from dystrophin deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with BMD are at increased risk of immobilization due to potential loss of ambulation, which is a risk factor for venous thromboembolism (e.g., deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism). However, pulmonary embolism is not the most common cause of death in patients with BMD.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with BMD have a slightly increased risk of urinary tract infection, which can lead to urosepsis, due to the increased prevalence of urological abnormalities (e.g., urinary incontinence, detrusor overactivity, voiding dysfunction). However, urosepsis is not the most common cause of death in individuals with BMD.
questions.hint: This adolescent patient's features (difficulty standing from a seated position, waddling gait, bilateral calf pseudohypertrophy) in conjunction with markedly elevated creatine kinase (CK) and an in-frame deletion of the dystrophin gene, are suggestive of Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD).
